title: The Monkey and the Crocodile
content: A clever monkey lived on a jamun tree by a river. One day, a crocodile tried to trick the monkey into coming onto his back to eat him. Using his wit, the monkey told the crocodile he had left his heart on the tree and must return to fetch it. The crocodile, fooled, brought him back to safety. The monkey's intelligence saved his life, proving that sharp thinking can triumph over brute strength.

title: The Brave Potter's Son
content: In a small village, a young potter's son discovered a fire threatening the granary at night. Everyone was asleep, but he ran through the smoke and carried buckets of water tirelessly until the fire died out. His courage saved the village's food supply and taught everyone that even the smallest hands can achieve great deeds when fear is ignored.

title: The Foolish Sage and the Hungry Crow
content: A wise but absent-minded sage often forgot to eat. One day, he found a hungry crow pecking at grains near his hut. Instead of scolding it, he shared his meager food. The crow, grateful, later returned with a treasure hidden in the forest, showing that even small acts of kindness can bring unexpected blessings.

title: The Clever Washerman
content: A dishonest rich man claimed that a poor washerman had stolen his gold coins. The village elders were about to punish the washerman, but he suggested testing the claim: they should weigh the washerman and the coins together, then separately. By clever reasoning, he revealed the man had hidden the coins in his own pockets. The washerman’s calm intelligence exposed injustice and taught the value of fairness and wit.

title: Birbal and the Well
content: A wealthy man once tricked a poor farmer into giving up his well, but refused him the water, saying he had only sold the well. The farmer went to Birbal, the wise minister in Emperor Akbar's court. Birbal smiled and told the wealthy man, 'If you sold the well, then you cannot keep your water in it. Either let the farmer use it or pay rent for keeping your water there.' The court laughed, and the farmer got justice. True wisdom lies in turning words of deceit into words of truth.

title: The Mango Tree’s Gift
content: In a village struck by drought, a mango tree stood tall but bore only a few fruits. Every day, thirsty travelers rested under its shade. A little boy who loved the tree noticed this and decided to pick the last ripe mango to share with the weakest traveler. The traveler was a wandering sage who blessed the tree. Overnight, the tree flourished with fruits again. The boy learned that even small kindness can bring life to many.

title: The King and the Two Women
content: Two women once came before a wise king, both claiming to be the mother of the same child. The king listened patiently, then declared: 'We shall cut the child in half, and each of you shall have a share.' One woman fell silent, but the other cried out, 'No! Give the child to her, only let him live!' The king smiled, for he knew then who the real mother was. Justice is not about punishment, but about truth revealed through compassion.

title: The Drum of Courage
content: Long ago, a village was terrorized by a wild tiger. Every night, its roar froze people in fear. A young shepherd, though trembling, carried his drum to the forest edge and beat it loudly, hoping to scare the beast. The tiger, never hearing such thunderous sound before, slunk away into the jungle. From then on, the shepherd’s drum became the village’s call of courage — teaching them that fear loses its power when faced with boldness.
